image.txt_cast:
En la época de Picasso, el hoy Teatro Rosalía de Castro se llamaba Teatro Principal. Tenía capacidad para 1.374 espectadores. Para situarlo, en la prensa de la época se indicaba que estaba situado frente a La Gran Antilla, la confitería aún hoy existente. La otra gran instalación cultural coruñesa era el Circo Coruñés, situado en La Marina.
En el Teatro Principal, Pablo Ruiz Picasso asistió seguramente a representaciones teatrales, pues entre sus dibujos coruñeses figura alguno que puede tener su origen en alguna obra de teatro que vio en A Coruña.
El Teatro Principal fue el primer edificio público de la ciudad que contó con luz eléctrica.
image.txt_gal:
In the Picasso years, the theatre now known as Rosalía de Castro was called Teatro Principal. It could sit 1,374 spectators. The press of the time would refer to the opposite sweet shop La Gran Antilla, still open today, in order to locate it. The other main Coruñan cultural venue was the Circo Coruñés, in La Marina.
Pablo Ruiz Picasso probably attended theatre performances at the Teatro Principal, since his Coruñan drawings include scenes that may have been inspired by plays seen in A Coruña.
The Teatro Principal was the first public building in the town to get electric light.
image.txt_eng:
According to John Richardson, one of his main biographers, Picasso first discovered female nudity in Riazor or Orzán beach. He was playing near the beach huts when "he found himself standing next to a naked woman, his eyes level with her pubic hair. The voyeuristic excitement associated with this occasion is something that Picasso never forgot. Forever afterward beach cabanas would be associated with the mystery of sex, especially in the late 1920s, when the little bathing huts at Dinard the scene of his amours with the teenage Marie-Thérèse Walter recur again and again in paintings (also poems) that are ostensibly playful and yet imbued with a mixture of sexuality and angst”.
A chronicle of the time described the beach as follows:"Riazor beach is on fashion. The cream of local society and visitors gather on it daily. This is what bathers discover at first sight: on the background, the sea spreads out in the distance until it mixes with the horizon; the sun shimmers above the sea’s wavy surface, and here and there, lively coloured umbrellas stand out on the wet sand (…)".
image.txt_fr:
À l'époque de Picasso, le Théâtre Rosalía de Castro était appelé Théâtre Principal. Il avait une capacité de 1.374 spectateurs. La presse de l'époque disait qu'il était en face de La Gran Antilla, la confiserie toujours existante. Le Circo Coruñés, situé sur l'avenue de La Marina, était l'autre installation culturelle importante de La Corogne.
Pablo Ruiz Picasso assista sûrement à des représentations théâtrales dans le Théâtre Principal, puisque parmi ses œuvres réalisées à La Corogne il y a quelques-unes inspirées possiblement dans des pièces jouées à La Corogne.
Le Théatre Principal fut le premier bâtiment public de la ville à avoir de l'électricité.
